title: Methane oxidation and diffusivity in mollisols under an urban forest in Argentina
abstract: Abstract Methane (CH4) oxidation in aerated soils is regulated mainly by physical factors which limit CH4 diffusion into the soil. Using the static chamber technique, we measured CH4 flux at the soil-atmosphere interface (SAI) and estimated its diffusivity (DsCH4) in a plantation of mixed deciduous species during a year. Methane diffusivity (DsCH4) was determined through two in situ techniques (Fick's Law -FL- and SF6 methods) and a particular soil parameter model (SP method). Mean CH4 oxidation was 15.61 ± 6.39 ng CH4/m2/s and varied significantly among seasons, coinciding with variation in soil water content (W%) (R = −0.8697, p = 5 × 10−4). CH4 diffusivity presented mean values of 0.0151 ± 0.0085 cm2/s and 0.0173 ± 0.0070 cm2/s for SP and FL methods respectively, and 0.0222 ± 0.0093 cm2/s for SF6 method, with a statistically significant difference from the other two (p

motivations: Methane oxidation in soils is a crucial process that is not well understood, particularly in relation to physical factors that limit methane diffusion.
There is a need to investigate methane diffusivity in soils under different environmental conditions to better understand methane oxidation processes.
objectives: Measure methane flux at the soil-atmosphere interface and estimate methane diffusivity in a mollisol under an urban forest in Argentina.
Compare different methods for determining methane diffusivity in soils, including Fick's Law, SF6, and soil parameter models.
methods: Use the static chamber technique to measure methane flux at the soil-atmosphere interface.
Employ Fick's Law, SF6, and soil parameter models to estimate methane diffusivity in soils.
Conduct field measurements over a year to capture seasonal variations in methane oxidation and diffusivity.
results: Methane oxidation rates vary significantly among seasons, influenced by changes in soil water content.
Methane diffusivity values differ depending on the method used, with the SF6 method yielding higher values than Fick's Law and soil parameter models.
